stem: Determine the significance of findings during peritoneal dialysis.
template: A client whose peritoneal outflow is cloudy likely has {{finding1}}, whereas a client with insufficient outflow should be encouraged to {{finding2}}.

rationale.correct: Cloudy peritoneal outflow is a hallmark sign of peritonitis, a serious infection of the peritoneal cavity. The cloudiness is due to an increased number of white blood cells fighting the infection. Insufficient outflow can be caused by catheter kinking, constipation, or the catheter tip being displaced against the abdominal wall or omentum. Changing positions, such as rolling from side to side, can help reposition the catheter and improve drainage. 1400: Assess the effluent. 1405: Reposition the client. 1410: Document the findings.
rationale.incorrect: Increasing fluid intake will not resolve outflow obstruction and may worsen fluid overload. Decreasing the dwell time will reduce the effectiveness of dialysis and does not address the mechanical issue of poor outflow. A normal finding would be clear or straw-colored effluent.
clinicalPearls: Always assess the peritoneal effluent for color, clarity, and odor. Cloudy effluent is a red flag for peritonitis.
Encourage patients to maintain regular bowel movements to prevent constipation, which can impede outflow.
Teach patients to avoid kinking the catheter and to monitor for signs of infection at the catheter insertion site.

questionTrap.trap: Assuming all poor outflow is due to a kink in the catheter.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: While a kink is a common cause, always assess the effluent for signs of peritonitis first. If no signs of infection are present, then investigate mechanical causes like kinks or constipation. Consider imaging if repositioning doesn't resolve the issue.

mnemonic.title: C-L-O-U-D-Y
mnemonic.expansion: Color (cloudy), Leukocytes (increased), Odor (foul), Underlying cause (infection), Drainage (poor), Yields (peritonitis)

reviewUnits.heading: Peritoneal Dialysis Complications
reviewUnits.body: Review the signs and symptoms of peritonitis, including abdominal pain, fever, nausea, vomiting, and cloudy dialysate. Understand the importance of sterile technique during exchanges to prevent infection.
reviewUnits.source: ATI Nursing: Content Mastery Series: Adult Medical Surgical Nursing. 11th ed.

reviewUnits.heading: Troubleshooting Peritoneal Dialysis Outflow Issues
reviewUnits.body: Learn the common causes of poor outflow, such as catheter kinking, constipation, and catheter displacement. Practice interventions to improve outflow, including repositioning the patient, checking for kinks, and administering stool softeners as needed.
reviewUnits.source: Lewis's Medical-Surgical Nursing: Assessment and Management of Clinical Problems, 12th ed.
